title: How to Connect Two Laptops Through a LAN

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Open the Control Panel.
steps.content: Open the Control Panel. Use the laptop that has files or folders you want to share. Use the following steps to open the Control Panel: Click the Windows Start button in the lower-left corner. Type "Control Panel". Click Control Panel .

steps.title: Type Network in the search bar.
steps.content: Type Network in the search bar. It's in the upper-right corner of the Control Panel window. This displays various network settings options.

steps.title: Click Network and Sharing Center.
steps.content: Click Network and Sharing Center . It's the green header at the top of your network settings.

steps.title: Click Change advanced sharing settings.
steps.content: Click Change advanced sharing settings . It's in the sidebar to the left.

steps.title: Ensure Network Discovery and Printer and File Sharing is enabled.
steps.content: Ensure Network Discovery and Printer and File Sharing is enabled. To turn on Network Discovery and Printer and File sharing is turned on, click the radio button next to "Turn on network discovery" and "Turn on printer and file sharing." These options are below "Private" and "Guest or Public (current profile)."

steps.title: Click Save Changes.
steps.content: Click Save Changes . It's at the bottom of the Control Panel window. This saves your settings changes.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . It has an icon that resembles a folder with a blue clip. It's in the taskbar at the bottom of the screen. If you do not see File Explorer in the taskbar, click the Windows Start button and type "File Explorer" to display File Explorer in the Start menu.

steps.title: Navigate to a file or folder you want to share.
steps.content: Navigate to a file or folder you want to share. You can share files and folders with other computers on your network. Use File Explorer to navigate to a file or folder you want to share. You can click the Quick Access folders in the menu to the left, or click a folder in the main window.

steps.title: Right-click a file or folder you want to share.
steps.content: Right-click a file or folder you want to share. This displays a menu to the right of the file or folder.

steps.title: Click Give access to.
steps.content: Click Give access to . It's in the menu that pops up when you right-click a file or folder. This displays a sub-menu to the side.

steps.title: Click Specific people.
steps.content: Click Specific people . It's at the bottom of the sub-menu next to "Give access to". This displays the Network Access menu.

steps.title: Click Share.
steps.content: Click Share . It's at the bottom of the Network Access menu. This shares the file or folder across your network and displays the network address for the folder.

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Open File Explorer on the second laptop.
steps.content: Open File Explorer on the second laptop. Use the laptop that you want to connect to. It has an icon that resembles a folder with a blue clip. You can either find it in the taskbar at the bottom of the screen or in the Windows Start menu.

steps.title: Click Network.
steps.content: Click Network . It's at the bottom of File Explorer in the menu bar to the left. This displays shared files and folders on the network.

steps.title: Enter the network address for the computer you want to access.
steps.content: Enter the network address for the computer you want to access. The computer's network address should be \\[computer name] . Replace "[computer name]" with the name of the computer you want to access. It can be a Mac or Windows computer. The computer you are trying to access must be powered on, logged in to and connected to the network.

steps.title: Enter the username and password and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Enter the username and password and press ↵ Enter . You'll need to enter the username and password for the computer you want to access. Then you should see all shared files and folders from the other computer.

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Click the Apple icon .
steps.content: Click the Apple icon . It's the Apple logo icon in the upper-left corner of the menu bar. This displays the Apple menu.

steps.title: Click System Preferences….
steps.content: Click System Preferences… . It's in the second option in the Apple Menu. This opens the System Preferences window.

steps.title: Click Sharing.
steps.content: Click Sharing . It has an icon that resembles a blue folder with a crosswalk sign on the front.

steps.title: Click the checkbox next to "File Sharing".
steps.content: Click the checkbox next to "File Sharing". It's in the box to the of the Sharing menu. This turns File Sharing on.

steps.title: Click File Sharing.
steps.content: Click File Sharing . It's the same option in the box on the left that you just checked. This displays the File Sharing options.

steps.title: Click + below the "Shared Folders" box.
steps.content: Click + below the "Shared Folders" box. This box displays all folders you have shared over the network. Click the Plus sign (+) at the bottom to add new folders.

steps.title: Select a folder.
steps.content: Select a folder. You can click any of the "Favorites" folders in the sidebar to the left, or any folder in the Finder window.

steps.title: Click Add.
steps.content: Click Add . It's in the lower-right corner of the window. This adds the folder to your list of shared folders, which can be accessed over the LAN.

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Open a new Finder window.
steps.content: Open a new Finder window. The Finder has an icon that resembles a blue and white smiley face. It's in the Dock at the bottom of the screen. Click this icon on the Mac you want to access shared folders through.

steps.title: Click Go.
steps.content: Click Go . It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen when you have the Finder open.

steps.title: Click Connect to Server….
steps.content: Click Connect to Server… . It's at the bottom of the drop-down menu below "Go".

steps.title: Enter the network address for the computer you want to access.
steps.content: Enter the network address for the computer you want to access. The network address for a shared computer is usually smb://[computer name] . Replace "[computer name]" with the actual name of the computer you want to access. This can be a Mac or Windows computer.

steps.title: Click Connect.
steps.content: Click Connect . It's in the lower-left corner of the "Connect to Server" window.

steps.title: Enter the username and password for the computer you want to access.
steps.content: Enter the username and password for the computer you want to access. After your Mac is able to establish a connection with the other computer, enter the username and password you use to log in to that computer. You can then access the Shared files and Folders in the Finder under "Shared" in the menu bar to the left. If you are trying to access a Windows computer, enter the email address and password for user's Microsoft account. [1] X Research source Make sure the other computer you are trying to access is powered on and logged into (not sleeping).

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Open your Control Panel.
steps.content: Open your Control Panel. Use the following steps to open the Control Panel. Click the Windows Start button in the lower-left corner. Type "Control Panel". Click Control Panel .

steps.title: Type Homegroup in the search bar.
steps.content: Type Homegroup in the search bar. It's in the upper-right corner of the Control Panel.

steps.title: Click the HomeGroup header.
steps.content: Click the HomeGroup header. It's the green header next to an icon that resembles a blue and green molecule. Homegroup is no longer available on Windows 10.

steps.title: Click Create a homegroup.
steps.content: Click Create a homegroup . It's the button in the bottom right of the window. Note that the button will only be enabled if you are not currently in a HomeGroup. If you are, leave your current HomeGroup.

steps.title: Click Next on the first screen of the window that pops up.
steps.content: Click Next on the first screen of the window that pops up. The first screen will just tell you what a HomeGroup does.

steps.title: Choose what sorts of files you want to share with other computers.
steps.content: Choose what sorts of files you want to share with other computers. Use the drop-down menus to select "Shared" next to the file types you want to share. You will be able to choose from: Pictures, Documents, Music, Printers, and Videos. Depending on your needs, select or deselect the file types.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . It's in the lower-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Write down the password.
steps.content: Write down the password. It's at the top of the screen. This will be the password that other devices will need to enter in order to connect to the HomeGroup. Then, click finish.

steps.title: Connect both laptops to your network.
steps.content: Connect both laptops to your network. You can connect both laptops using a wireless connection, or you can connect both laptops to a LAN port on your modem or router using an Ethernet cable.

steps.title: Open the Control Panel.
steps.content: Open the Control Panel. Use the laptop that has files or folders you want to share with a second laptop. Use the following steps to open the Control Panel: Click the Windows Start button in the lower-left corner. Type "Control Panel". Click Control Panel .

steps.title: Type Homegroup in the search bar.
steps.content: Type Homegroup in the search bar. It's in the upper-right corner of the Control Panel.

steps.title: Click HomeGroup header.
steps.content: Click HomeGroup header. It's the green header next to an icon that resembles a blue and green molecule. HomeGroup is no longer available on Windows 10.

steps.title: Click Join now.
steps.content: Click Join now . A new HomeGroup displayed on the HomeGroup window. Click the new HomeGroup and click Join Homegroup in the lower-right corner.

steps.title: Enter the password when prompted.
steps.content: Enter the password when prompted. Use the password that was displayed on the first computer. You can now use the drop-down menus to select which file types you want to share on the HomeGroup network.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . It has an icon that resembles a folder with a blue clip. Click this icon in the taskbar or Windows Start menu.

steps.title: Click HomeGroup.
steps.content: Click HomeGroup . It's in File Explorer. This displays user accounts that are part of the HomeGroup network. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click a username.
steps.content: Click a username. This is the Windows username for the person you want to access across the network. This displays the shared files and folders the user has shared across the network.

steps.title: Double-click the file or folder you want to access.
steps.content: Double-click the file or folder you want to access. This allows you to access the shared file across the local area network.

steps.title: Obtain a network crossover cable.
steps.content: Obtain a network crossover cable. This is a type of Ethernet cable used for connecting two computers to one another. If you have an older computer, you must use a crossover cable. A regular Ethernet cable will not work on older computers. There is no aesthetic difference between the two cables. Ask your store representative to find you a cross over cable just to be safe.

steps.title: Plug each end of the cable into a network port of each laptop.
steps.content: Plug each end of the cable into a network port of each laptop. The network port is what you connect your Ethernet cable to usually. The cable will click when successfully connected to the network port. Note that some newer laptops do not have a network port. Some laptop manufacturers have decided not to include a network port so that the laptop is thinner or lighter. If this is the case, you will need to connect your laptops to a wireless network.

steps.title: Navigate to your Control Panel on both computers.
steps.content: Navigate to your Control Panel on both computers. Use the following steps to open the Control Panel: Click the Windows Start button in the lower-left corner. Type "Control Panel". Click Control Panel .

steps.title: Type System in the search bar on both computers.
steps.content: Type System in the search bar on both computers. The search bar is in the upper-right corner of the Control Panel.

steps.title: Click the System header.
steps.content: Click the System header. It's the green header next to an icon that resembles a computer screen. You should see information about your computer such as Manufacturer, Model, etc.

steps.title: Scroll down and click Change Settings.
steps.content: Scroll down and click Change Settings . It's on the right side of the screen below "Computer name, domain, and workgroup settings." A new window should pop up titled "System Properties."

steps.title: Click Change.
steps.content: Click Change . It's at the bottom of the "System Properties" window. This displays the computer name and workgroup name.

steps.title: Enter in the same name for the workgroup on both PCs.
steps.content: Enter in the same name for the workgroup on both PCs. It does not matter what the name is, as long as both computers use the same workgroup name.

steps.title: Type Network in the Control Panel search bar on both laptops.
steps.content: Type Network in the Control Panel search bar on both laptops. It's in the upper-right corner of the Control Panel. For Windows 7, Vista, and XP Users: Open up "Network Settings" directly from your Control Panel. Search for it in the search box in the upper right corner of the window.

steps.title: Click View Network Connections.
steps.content: Click View Network Connections . It's below the "Network and Sharing Center" header in the Control Panel.

steps.title: Right-click Ethernet.
steps.content: Right-click Ethernet . It's in your "Network Connections" window. There may be multiple "Ethernet" options. Right-click the one that does not have a red "x" in the lower-left corner of the icon next to it.

steps.title: Click Properties.
steps.content: Click Properties . It's at the bottom of the menu that appears when you right-click "Ethernet".

steps.title: Select Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) and click Properties.
steps.content: Select Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) and click Properties . You can find "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)" in the list of items. Click it to select it, and then click Properties below the list of items.

steps.title: Click on the "Use the following IP address" option.
steps.content: Click on the "Use the following IP address" option. This will allow you to manually enter an address.

steps.title: Enter in these values for each PC:
steps.content: Enter in these values for each PC: Use the fields below "Use the following IP address" to enter the following on both computers. It's is important that the last number for the IP address is different for both computers. PC 1 IP Address: 192.168.0.1 Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0 Default Gateway: This field blank PC 2 IP Address: 192.168.0.2 Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0 Default Gateway: Leave this field blank.

steps.title: Click "OK" to apply the settings.
steps.content: Click "OK" to apply the settings. You should now be able to share files across two computers over your connected LAN cable. You might need to restart each computer for the changes to take effect. [3] X Research source
